abstract.text: Donate app-specific content, use Siri’s contact suggestions, and adopt the latest platform features to create a more consistent messaging experience.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Improving interactions between Siri and your messaging app

inlineContent.text: SiriKit provides a number of supplementary APIs that are specific to messaging apps. Adopt these APIs and provide the required information so your messaging app can:
influence the choices Siri makes when routing a message-related request
provide more accurate recipient options when sending messages with Siri
enable someone to unsend or edit a message sent with Siri
provide richer information about message attachments for Siri to announce or display
In addition to messaging apps, the content of the first two sections is applicable to apps using SiriKit’s VoIP-related intents. For example,
For information about how Apple protects people’s privacy when your messaging or VoIP app shares information with the system, see the Siri section of

content.text: Donate contact vocabulary and app interactions to Siri

inlineContent.text: Siri integrates with the Contacts app and uses the app’s contact database to suggest message recipients. If your app manages its own database of contacts, independent of the Contacts app, donate the names of those contacts using
to enable Siri to locate them when handling requests. If your messaging app supports group chats, use the same APIs to donate the in-app names of those group chats.
To donate the required vocabulary, create instances of
. Set
to the name of the contact or group chat, and
to the value of the contact’s
property — the value your app uses to uniquely identify that object.
Order the collection of speakable strings by importance. For more information, see
When someone performs an action in your messaging app and the app includes support for the corresponding intent, such as sending or replying to a message, create and donate an instance of
to make Siri aware of the action. If your app uses the system’s Contacts database, reduce ambiguity by setting the
property for each of the interaction’s contacts to their corresponding database identifier; otherwise, set their
property to the unique value your app uses to identify them.

content.text: Choose recipients from the matches Siri suggests

inlineContent.text: When Siri asks your intent handler to resolve a message’s recipients, it provides a collection of
objects — one for each recipient. Using data from the Contacts app (for example, work or family relationships), Siri populates the
property on each instance of
with zero or more proposed contact matches, enabling your app to provide more accurate recipient options to the person sending the message.
Use the following guidance to determine which
method to invoke based on the matches Siri provides:
If the
array contains a single match and your app successfully identifies that person by their
or

method to resolve the recipient.
If the array contains multiple people and those people each have distinct
or
values, disregard those your app can’t identify and then respond according to the number of remaining matches. For example, if there are still two or more matches, use the
method to ask the person interacting with Siri to choose.
If the array contains multiple people and they all have the same
, disambiguate using
instead. If your app doesn’t use handles, simply pass any match to the
method.
If the array is empty or the property is
, search your app’s contacts for people matching those in the
property of
instead. Use the
method that best describes the outcome of that search.
If your messaging app allows people to attach a custom image to each of their contacts, use the
property on
to provide that image when returning an instance of

content.text: Enable people to unsend or edit sent messages

inlineContent.text: In iOS 16 and later, after a person sends a message from the Messages app or Siri, within a short duration after sending, they can unsend or edit that message. To add the same functionality to your messaging app, perform the following:
Whenever you create an instance of
, populate the
property with one or more
objects. Set each object’s
property to the value your app uses to uniquely identify the sent message. The system passes those values to your app when the app needs to take action on behalf of the sender.
To support message unsending, create an object that conforms to the
protocol and implement the required
method. On receipt of an unsend request, Siri invokes this method and provides an instance of
. Use the values in the object’s
property to identify those messages in your app and take the action necessary to unsend them.
Similarly, to support message editing, create an object that conforms to the
protocol and implement the required
method. On receipt of an edit request, Siri invokes this method and provides an instance of
. The object contains a single message identifier for you to identify the corresponding message in your app. If you specify multiple
objects when originally sending the message, the system returns the last one with a message type of
The following shows an example implementation of message unsending:

code: guard let identifiers = intent.messageIdentifiers, identifiers.count > 0 else {

content.text: Return attachment metadata in Siri search results

inlineContent.text: When someone asks Siri for information about their sent or received messages, Siri creates an instance of
and requests your app to fulfill that intent. If the messages in your app’s results include attachments, use the appropriate attachment-related initializers on
to provide additional information for Siri to announce or display. For example, you can include an array of
instances that describe each file (including their content type), or if a single message has several attachments, provide the count of attachments instead.
For more information, see the following:
Action
Initializer
Provide one or more message attachments
Provide information about a URL in a message
Provide the total number of attachments

abstract.text: Empower people to customize interactions for your app on their device.
An object that describes a file.
An interaction between the user and your app involving an intent object.
An object that describes a sent or received message.
The message’s unique identifier.
The message content is text-based.
Information about a person participating in a SiriKit interaction.
The Contacts database identifier for the person.
The unique identifier that your app uses to identify the person.
An image of the person.
The unique handle that your app assigns to the person.
The list of matches Siri provides for you to resolve or disambiguate.
A resolution result for a user as a parameter of an intent.
Creates an object whose resolution requires the user to select from among the specified objects.
Creates an object whose resolution involves the successful matching of the specified parameter.
A request to list the messages that match the specified criteria.
A request to send a message to the designated recipients.
The array of users to receive the message.
Your app’s response to a send message intent.
A custom phrase to be resolved by an Intents extension.
A request to start an audio or video call with one or more users.
An object for registering user-specific vocabulary that Siri requests might include.
Registers the specified vocabulary strings with the user.
Empower users to interact with their devices through voice, intelligent suggestions, and personalized workflows.
Add custom intents and parameters to help users interact more quickly and effectively with Siri and the Shortcuts app.
